answerText: Kepler's Second Law [10] For a body experiencing an inverse-square attractive force, this special vector is conserved. It is equal to the cross product of the linear momentum and angular momentum, minus mass times the force constant times the unit position vector.
heading: ACF Winter |2009 | Stanford A and Maryland A and University of Illinois at Chicago | 10 | Science | Physics | College
subject: Science
question: Question: Answer the following about orbital mechanics, for 10 points each.   [10] This law, a consequence of conservation of angular momentum, says that an orbiting body sweeps out equal areas in equal time.
